newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES LARGELY SOFTER AFTER TENDER.
newsitem.headline: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES LARGELY SOFTER AFTER TENDER.

text.p: Short-term trading rates on Zimbabwe's money market were quoted largely softer on Friday following a drop in the benchmark treasury bill rate at Thursday's weekly auction, dealers said.
They said a two-percent drop in the central Reserve Bank rediscount rate, its landing rate to commercial banks, had also contributed towards a fall in other rates.
"The rediscount rate obviously had to come down because other rates were coming down. But I believe it's still too high considering other rates are now in their lower twenties," one dealer commented.
On Friday, discount houses were buying treasury bills from the central bank at 23.12 percent, down from 23.73 percent last week, and selling them on the market at around 22.5 percent.

NCD bills maturing after 30, 60 and 90 days were being bought at a steady 24.5 percent and sold at 23.5 while bankers acceptance bills were buying softer at 23.75 from 24 percent but selling unchanged at 23.5 percent.
Call money rates slipped to a 22 and 22.75 percentage range from between 23 and 23.5 percent in a market which opened in surplus of Z$148 million, up from Z$78 million on Thursday morning.
